article.description: David West scored 23 points, proving that no one on Cincinnati's front line could guard him, and No. 16 Xavier held on for a 50-44 victory Saturday on its rival's court.
article.headline: Cincinnati does not have answer for West

images.name: Xavier_celabration 120702 inline
images.caption: David West and Romain Sato celebrate Saturday's victory.

article.linkText: Xavier holds on against stubborn Bearcats
article.story:
CINCINNATI (AP) -- David West missed his first shot, banking it
too hard off the backboard. He missed a layup and a dunk, too.

<photo1>He didn't miss much else in Xavier's biggest grudge match of the
season.

West scored 23 points, proving that no one on Cincinnati's front
line could guard him, and No. 16 Xavier held on for a 50-44 victory
Saturday on its rival's court.

Xavier (4-1) has won five of the last seven games in the
crosstown series. West's fourth and final game against Cincinnati
(3-2) was by far his most impressive.

The Musketeers set up their offense to get him the ball and let
him shoot.

"He had to play well for us to win today,'' coach Thad Matta
said. "That was the bottom line.''

The preseason All-America and two-time Atlantic 10 Player of the
Year took on all comers, and handled them easily. He also made the
game's statement play on defense, emphatically swatting Field
Williams' jumper over the Cincinnati bench.

Overall, he was 10-of-19 from the field, the only player who
made more than half of his shots in a game dictated by tight
defense.

"We knew that if we executed out sets, we would have an
advantage,'' West said, referring to the plays that got him the
ball. "It paid off.''

Cincinnati power forward Jason Maxiell had bragged that he was
tougher than West and would shut him down if he got the chance to
guard him. The foul-prone Maxiell never got the opportunity, and
grudgingly conceded that West made the difference.

"He made the tough shots that put them up,'' said Maxiell, who
had eight points.

Cincinnati went with its assortment of unimpressive centers, and
West had his way with each of them. He drove past and shot over
Kareem Johnson and Rod Flowers while scoring 13 in the first half.

The Bearcats were forced to go to zone defense -- something coach
Bob Huggins dislikes -- to keep West from blowing the game open all
by himself.

After Cincinnati cut the lead to two points on Williams'
3-pointer with 29 seconds left, Dedrick Finn made both ends of a
one-and-one. West then rebounded Williams' miss and made both free
throws to snap Cincinnati's streak of 20 straight home wins.

At the buzzer, Musketeers players celebrated on court, then
walked off, rankling their counterparts.

"They ran off without shaking hands,'' said Leonard Stokes, who
led Cincinnati with 13 points. "That's what hurts the most about
this game. It's respect.''

"I guess you're supposed to shake hands,'' West said. "I just
got caught up in the emotion. I didn't worry about their guys as
much as congratulating my teammates.''

The game started like most -- so much intensity that neither team
could get into a flow for a few minutes. Xavier never trailed after
putting together a 13-point run that featured two jumpers and a
3-pointer by West.

Midway through the half, Xavier led 17-6 and Cincinnati had made
only two of its 12 shots from the field. Xavier's switching
man-to-man defense blanketed the Bearcats' outside shooters.

Huggins, who had a massive heart attack Sept. 28, watched
helplessly in the second half as Xavier took control upfront. West
scored three straight from right under the basket and Anthony
Myles' layup put Xavier up 33-22.

West then made his worst decision, drawing his third foul while
contesting a rebound. West went to the bench, and Cincinnati went
on a 9-0 spurt that got the Bearcats within two points and set up
the close finish.

Cincinnati dominated last year's game at Xavier, winning by 20
points. West severely sprained his ankle in the first half, and
said afterward that if he'd been healthy, the Musketeers would have
won.

In the rematch, the Bearcats shot only 30 percent from the field
as they lost on their home court for the first time since Feb. 18,
2001, when they lost in overtime to Marquette.

Many of the anti-Xavier signs in the red-clad crowd were
directed at West -- one told him to stop crying, and another called
him a "Future NBA Bust.''

Cincinnati athletic director Bob Goin went on the court for a
pregame presentation, and took a minute to ask the crowd to show
sportsmanship. The Bearcats' reputation took a hit last month when
their football team brawled with Hawaii on the field in Honolulu.

The capacity crowd of 13,176 was so loud that both teams had to
call plays from the bench by holding up cards.

The highlight of last year's blowout came at halftime, when a
former local high school basketball player made a halfcourt shot
and won $1 million from a chili parlor. This year's contestant in
the annual promotion came up way short.
